awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Fully Screen Printed Electric Cell-Substrate Impedance Sensing Toxicity Assay
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a new product testing tool to evaluate potential human toxicity of products in development. Current practices that test a product’s effects on humans consist of lengthy, expensive, and harmful animal studies. Given the cost, many animal toxicity screenings often happen in later product development stages – at which point millions of development dollars have already been spent. Major financial losses follow unfavorable screening results. Specifically, this technology will be developed with the intention to not only save millions of dollars downstream, but also maintain animal welfare and ethics in the product development process across industries. Compared to the current market offerings by others, this novel cell toxicity assay is intuitive and easy to manage with respect to time and the number of samples, while providing a rapid, accurate assessment.  The global toxicology testing market is projected to reach $14.4 billion by 2025. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is aimed at developing a novel, scalable in vitro toxicity assay that leverages a cellular-electrode interface bioprinting technology. Toxicological testing occurs toward the end of product development of a drug or consumer product after millions of dollars have already been poured into R&D.  These in vivo screens are expensive, harmful to animals, and have the potential to kill products after years of pre-market development. Bioprinting has emerged as a promising new approach for biofabricating models and systems for in vitro toxicology screening in an attempt to address the ethical and financial burden aforementioned. Yet, despite revolutionary potential, traditional bioprinting has technical and commercial drawbacks (e.g. cell damage, low throughput, high cost, inflexible). This proposal is designed to address those drawbacks by developing 1) a novel method to biofabricate tissues using an innovative bioprinting technique and 2) an integration of electrode sensors to quantitatively measure cell health and viability via electrical signal output correlations. Experimental success of tissue fabrication and electrode-cellular measurements will be determined by greater than 80% of cellular viability following novel bioprinting method and a correlation value of r> 0.6 between electrical impedance readings and canonical molecular toxicity analyses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of our SBIR Phase I research was focused on determining the viability of screen-printing human cells for scalable in vitro toxicity screening.

The initial research was focused on assembling screens with reinforced wooden frames and using hydrogels as a printing medium. We found that the curing process for producing precise patterns was sensitive to UV exposure time. In addition, the mesh size of the screen affected the gel deposition pattern - different mesh sizes allowing different amounts of material to pass through. The selection of the hydrogel composition was critical for maintaining the integrity of deposition and cell placement. The researchers explored different hydrogels and ultimately used polyethylene glycol and poly-L-lysine (PEG-PLL) as a printing medium due to its biocompatibility and structural stability.

The second aim of the research focused on the integration of a cellular-electrode interface. The researchers constructed electrodes using conductive ink screen-printed onto glass cover slips. They tested different ink conductivities and viscosities to ensure optimal ink deposition. The design of the electrodes consisted of a broken outer semi-circle and a solid inner full circle. Different mesh sizes were also investigated to maximize the resolution of the printed electrodes. The researchers found that carbon inks were well-suited for standardizing the data collection process as a cellular interface sensor. They also demonstrated that impedance spectroscopy using the screen-printed electrodes was a viable method for measuring cellular responses.

The third aim of the research aimed to achieve real-time monitoring with electrical impedance measurements. The researchers investigated the effects of toxicological agents on screen printed cells using HepG2 hepatocytes. They tested the cytotoxic agent Ethanol and observed changes in cellular responses through impedance spectroscopy recordings. The researchers found that Ethanol induced an observable shift in cellular responses. However, more work needs to be done to fully validate the methodology and expand it to other clinically relevant cytotoxic agents. The fourth aim of the research focused on developing a multilayer printed cellular-electrode assay. The researchers encountered challenges in printing multiple layers due to the elastic nature of hydrogels and cells, and future approaches may involve printing individual layers on a biocompatible material for stacking.


Last Modified: 06/21/2023
Modified by: Rashi Sultania
